title: Bomb explodes near Afghan election rally, killing 24, but president unhurt
text:
Afghan security forces keep watch at the site of a blast in Kabul September 17, 2019. (Omar Sobhani/Reuters)

A blast targeting a campaign rally held by Afghan President Ashraf Ghani on Tuesday killed 24 but left the country’s leader unharmed, according to a local health official.

Thousands of Afghans packed an open airfield in a police training compound in the country’s northern Parwan province to hear Ghani speak Tuesday morning. Qasim Sangin, head of the Parwan province health department said there were 32 wounded and women and children were among the dead.

The blast occurred just moments after Ghani arrived at the venue, and even though the explosion was audible, the campaign event continued undeterred. Ghani delivered a boilerplate stump speech praising local leadership to the crowd.

Wahida Shahkar, the spokeswoman for the provincial governor in Parwan said the blast targeting the campaign rally was carried out by a suicide bomber driving a motorcycle.

Presidential elections in Afghanistan are scheduled for the end of the month after the failure of peace talks with the militant Taliban group.

Ghani has held a series of large campaign rallies across the country in recent weeks without incident as he makes his bid for a second term. Tuesday’s rally, as with others, was held amid tight security with all attendees subjected to multiple searches.

[With U.S.-Taliban peace talks canceled, Afghan president is on the hot seat]

Also Tuesday a blast occurred outside the compound housing the United States Embassy in Kabul, according to a Ministry of Interior statement that did not include information regarding casualties.

Ghani’s government has emphasized security as Afghans prepare to head to the polls later this month. Some 72,000 security forces have been deployed to protect the vote and more than two thousand polling stations will be closed on election day due to inadequate security.

No group has claimed responsibility for either attack. The Taliban has openly threatened to derail the election process.

George reported from Kabul.
